post_text: BGA received its official Green Ribbon Award in Washington D.C. yesterday at a ceremony celebrating 34 schools from around the country recognized for their continued work supporting green and sustainable practices and curriculum. BGA is one of the few urban schools in this group, with a career technology and education program in environmental science, and sustaining the work in a 125-year old building not specifically built to support STEM. Receiving the award from Stuart Levenbach, chief of staff at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (left) and Frank Brogan, assistant secretary for elementary and secondary education at the U.S. Department of Education (right) are, right to left, headmaster Matt Holzer, CTE teacher Chris Donnelly, Physics teacher Erica Wilson, board chair Alex Chu, and BPS sustainability manager, Katherine Walsh.

post_text: This morning at the Great Hall of the Massachusetts State House, BGA received the Green Ribbon Schools Award from the MA Secretary of Education, Jim Peyser, making it only the second BPS district school to receive the award in its 25-year history. Ipswich Middle-High School and Wellesley Public Schools also received Green Ribbon Award. Thirty other schools from all over the state also received Certificates of Excellence for their work in greening education.
